content.title: Crawford Classification of Thoracoabdominal Aortic Aneurysms - Detailed
content.description: Comprehensive breakdown of the Crawford classification system for thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysms, including surgical implications and spinal cord ischemia risk for each extent.
content.definition: The Crawford classification divides TAAAs into four extents based on proximal and distal boundaries, with each type having different surgical approaches, visceral reconstruction needs, and spinal cord ischemia risk.

extent_I.boundaries: From left subclavian artery to suprarenal aorta

extent_II.boundaries: From left subclavian artery to aortic bifurcation

extent_III.boundaries: From mid-descending thoracic aorta to aortic bifurcation
extent_III.includes: Distal half of descending thoracic + all abdominal

extent_IV.includes: All abdominal aorta including visceral segment

learning_objectives: Correlate extent with spinal cord ischemia risk
Understand visceral reconstruction requirements per extent
clinical_pearls: Extent II has highest morbidity/mortality due to complete aortic replacement
T8-L2 is the critical zone for artery of Adamkiewicz origin
Staged repair (Elephant Trunk) can reduce Extent II cord ischemia
CSF drainage reduces spinal cord ischemia by 50%+
